utterances: I do want to point to a great poll that was just done by Essence and the Black Women's Roundtable.

And they showed that, for black women, the most important issues are criminal justice and policing reform, affordable health care, the rise in hate crimes and racism, equal rights and equal pay, gun violence and gun safety, affordable housing and gentrification.
OK.
So these are the issues that are important to black people.
And they want the candidates to talk about it.
So I think that shows that there isn't any type of enthusiasm gap, nationally.
People are ready and waiting for these issues to be addressed.
A'shanti, just - how do you understand this whole question of electability versus policy excitement?
You remember that some people say that, you know, Democrats want to fall in love and Republicans fall in line.

And there is this whole argument about whether candidates care more about somebody who they - do the voters care more about somebody who they think is electable versus somebody whose policies they absolutely, you know, support.
And, obviously, the polls say, among Democrats writ large, beating Donald Trump is priority one.
But what are you seeing?
How is this translating out where - in the spaces that you're in?
From - what I'm seeing is - and, again, I talked about this before.
When they talk about electability by default terms that we're talking about is a straight, white man.
But as you're seeing these candidates come out and talk about their issues, they want someone who is going to do things and fight Trump.
And they're particularly seeing with the Democratic candidates is that there are so many of those candidates that can do both of those things.
So that's why you see so many people rising in the polls because electability is important.
But they also know that they need someone who's going to be there and get things done because the country has been on the wrong track for so long since this man came into office.
Monika, what about you?
When you're out on the campaign trail on this whole question of electability versus - of, you know, a person you absolutely agree with, what did voters say to you?
I think voters really - so I'm elected, currently, in a part of my district.
And so what I hear voters saying loud and clear to me is, can you and will you do the same thing that you've done for - if elected to Congress?
We want to know that you're going to remain connected to this community in sharing the voices that you hear here.
My authenticity is - what led me to run this race is because voters said we've never really had somebody who's been true to their word and remained in our community and remain visible and viable.
That's what people want to know.
They want to know what you really are able to do and what you're willing to do.
But your prior elected office - you're finding it to be an asset not a liability.
I've found it to be an asset.
I'm - very similar district breakout that I've won three times for my school board.
And so I think while it expands to five other counties that I'm currently not elected in, very similar demographics and numbers.
And so I really think people see that as an asset, that I have been elected before and can speak to what I've done as an elected official, which I think is what people want to know.
What are you going to do?
And I can talk to - talk about that.
And they can also look at it.
And, Cori, what about you?
Do I understand it right that you're - you have been at least a national surrogate for Bernie Sanders?
Is that correct?
Cori?
Yes, I am now, currently.
And the - according to a Morning Consult poll and a number of polls, it emerges that Bernie Sanders is polling around 20% with all black voters.
But that's compared to 41% with Vice President Biden.
And African American voters seem to be kind of the - powering Biden's lead in the polls right now.
How do you understand that?
I understand it when I am speaking for Senator Sanders, when I'm knocking doors and people are finding out who he is.
I'll tell you someone from Bernie Sanders' campaign came to St. Louis.
And I took them into Ferguson, and we went to a park.
And people were asking, who's this person?
And I'm like, oh, they're with Bernie Sanders' campaign.
And they went, oh, my gosh.
We want to get to know.
And so there was this excitement.
And so it's not about people just wanting to support Biden.
People are supporting him because (unintelligible) President Barack Obama.
But when people get a chance to meet Senator Sanders or hear about him right in their neighborhoods when they're - when - knocks on their doors, those irons are changing.
I - and so, for me, it's not just about - to me, electability is having those policies.
And I agree with the - with the two other people...
A'shanti.
...On the panel, with A'shanti and Monika...
Monika.
I - oh, I'm sorry.
Monika.
I agree that we need people that show up.
We need to - authenticity.
I believe that's what people want to see, and that's who I've been in this community.
And so that's what electability should look like.
It should look like the people that are here, the people that have been doing the work, the people that are tried and true and those that show up and stay in the community and have the policy.
That's what electability should be.
Well, we can't wait to continue talking with all of you as this election season unfolds.
Thank you all so much for joining us and thank you, especially on a busy campaign weekend - taking time to talk with us.
That was Cori Bush, who's a Democratic candidate from Missouri's 1st Congressional District.
A'shanti Gholar was also with us.
She's political director for Emerge America.
She was with us via Skype.
And you can hear that she's at the conference in the background.
And Monika Johnson-Hostler was kind enough to step away for a minute to talk to us.
She's a Democratic candidate for North Carolina's 2nd Congressional District.
Thank you all so much for talking to us.
Thank you.
Thank you.
This is Day to Day.
I'm Alex Cohen.
The General Motors presentation at the North American International Auto Show yesterday had a few surprise guests.
One of them was the governor of Michigan, Jennifer Granholm.
Madeleine Brand, on the scene there in Detroit, spoke to the governor before the event to ask her about the outlook for the future of the car industry in Michigan.
Governor Jennifer Granholm, welcome back to Day to Day.
Thank you, Madeleine.
Governor, when we last spoke in December, the automakers were still seeking a federal bailout.
Well, they got one, $17.4 billion, a lot less than what they had been asking for.
Will it be enough, or will they need more?
Well, it won't be enough to be able to completely transform the auto industry.
You may recall they were asking for 34 billion, and so they got about half of that - two of the three did.
But it is a start to be able to complete the conversation with the Obama administration.
Everyone wants to see transformation of the auto industry and a move toward electric vehicles and hybrid plug-ins and all of that.
And the auto industry wants to get there as well.
It just requires a significant amount of investment.
Well, what do you want specifically from the Obama administration and from a new Congress?
I think there needs to be several things that happen.
First of all, what they are talking about right now is significant.
Economic recovery plan and an investment in the electric grid is going to have to be part of the system of delivery of energy to vehicles.
And so if you want to plug in your electric car, you have to make sure when you plug it in that the grid is able to provide you with the energy, right?
So you have to have a smart grid that is able to do that.
And that investment's going to have to happen as part of this.
You have to have the ability for people to buy electric cars.
And right now, the battery is very expensive.
And so tax credits to be able to level out that playing field is very, very important, so that when people buy these electric cars, they're not, you know, they don't have to mortgage their future.
Well, what you're talking about, these are massive projects which could take many, many years to complete.
Some are and some are not.
Obviously, the upgrade of the electric grid across the nation is a massive project, and that's going to require significant commitment on the part of the Obama administration long term.
But certainly the investment right now in research development, assembly, production of batteries, that is much more short-term.
And they are on the cusp of a lot of breakthroughs in battery technology that will enable people to go for 40 miles, 100 miles, on a single charge.
That's exactly what's necessary, and they need to be able to retool.

They, meaning the auto companies, need to be able to retool their factories to produce vehicles that can accept a battery of that size into the vehicle and not have it powered by necessarily an internal combustion engine, which is what they're used to.
So that can happen rather quickly.
In fact, at the auto show, you'll see a lot of cars that are in the pipeline now that are plug-in electric vehicles.
Not just the Volt, but every one of the automakers have a plan for a plug-in electric vehicle.
And that's very exciting.
The automakers need to present their restructuring plans in February.
And I'm wondering - we've been talking about what you want the government to do, the federal government.
What do you want the automakers to do and to say that they're doing in terms of changing the way they operate?
Everybody has a role to play.
And certainly the auto industry's got a very significant role in making us energy independent.

I think they've got to demonstrate that they are not Luddites, that they are not going to slow down or resist the desire to move to more fuel-efficient vehicles or vehicles that don't run on gasoline at all.
So that, I think, they will be presenting a plan to do.
And obviously you can't do that overnight.

But ultimately I believe that after this period of restructuring and refocus, that we will emerge - we as a state, but certainly the auto industry as an industry - will emerge with a stronger, leaner, and more fuel-efficient industry, more fuel-efficient vehicle.
Many auto analysts believe that there won't be a recovery for many, many years in terms of how many vehicles are sold.
It won't reach the heyday of the last few years, possibly until 2012 or possibly beyond.
And, you know, one analyst is quoted as saying that the internal problems of the Big Three automakers are so great there is no way they can survive without government help for several years.
Do you agree with that?
I think there has to be a partnership that is ongoing, like there is a partnership with the auto industries in other countries.

They recognize that everyone has a role to play, that the government needs to step up to the plate and provide universal access to affordable health care and not put that burden entirely on industry, whether it's auto industry or any other industry.
That has to be a partnership with the auto - with any company and with the federal government.
So they have a role to play in that.
They have a role to play in investment and research and development, like they do in other countries.
So, yes, there is going to have to be a long-term partnership with the recognition that long term the United States as a nation needs to be independent of foreign oil.
Is one problem, though, that with falling consumption and falling sales that the auto industry won't have the money or the ability really to invest in R&D?
(Through interpreter) From where you are, I can't recognize you.
I can see shapes, nothing else.
Isn't this guy a Republican?
Pino's biotech operation uses cell cultures that need to be kept refrigerated.
He has a pretty big generator, but he was so worried someone would steal it that he removed the trailer hitch on it, so it couldn't be hauled away.
Phone service in one town went down because someone stole the generator that powered the cell tower.
When U.S.
military officials met with Mayor Roberto Pagan in the town of Lares, rampant generator theft was one problem he highlighted.
(Speaking Spanish).
It's mostly young guys,"" he says, ""mostly stealing generators to sell them.
When everyone needs a generator and none are available,"" he says, ""they'll pay almost anything for them."" And if they don't steal the generator, they might steal the diesel.
A big question is how long this generator society can keep going.
It's not exactly efficient.
Arnaldo Cruz is research director at the Foundation for Puerto Rico.
A lot of these small businesses are opening with a generator, but they're losing money.
If - I talked to a few of them, and they're like, listen, I used to pay, like, $200 for electricity.
And now, I'm paying, like, $800 for diesels.
They have diesel, but their operation is not profitable anymore.
So what do they do?
That's Laura Om's problem.
She owns a restaurant and a hair salon, but they're closed, and she's not ready to reopen.
It's like $3,000 a month (laughter) for diesel.
I talk to my accountant, like, at least, every two days.
It's not opening just to open because it can be worse.
So you really have to analyze if it's worth it.
So generators not only are not the long-term solution to Puerto Rico's power problem, they're barely the short-term solution.
Tom Gjelten, NPR News, San Juan.
